name: HCL Color
description:
The HCL color space equalizes the apparent lightness of hues and allows for more precise control over contrast. 


This is helpful for things like data visualization that convey meaning with color, where using regular HSV/L may lead to seeing patterns that aren't there because hues have different lightness and our brains find lightness more important than hue.


It also eliminates unwanted surprises should your work be viewed in B/W (printed etc.)


C is colorfulness. Its numeric value is somewhat arbitrary, so I normalize it to 100% at the edge.


The shown contrast ratio is against white in sRGB. Luv or Lab can be chosen as the underlying color space.


Color blindness can be simulated with the three rings in the top right corner. Each ring will cycle through Normal->Weak->Blind (the center dot includes blue-mono and mono). Holding Shift will toggle Normal<->Weak, holding Ctrl will toggle Normal<->Blind.


The arrow keys move the selected handle in small increments (hold Shift to move both handles). Shift also locks dragging to one axis. Alt+R resets the plugin to the default state.


Clicking a swatch copies its hex value to the clipboard.
